text:
Applications that worked in previous versions (up to 5.5.20 is the last one I
tested) no longer works. Axis 1.4 generated-web service related classes now
gives a non serializable error that also shuts down the server on the service call.
creator: javier.ortiz.78@gmail.com

text: Version tested is 6.0.13 which is not listed as an option in the version field.
creator: javier.ortiz.78@gmail.com

text:
There isn't enough information here for us to reproduce the problem. A ready to
run test case would be ideal.
creator: markt@apache.org

text:
The running aplication is an open source program. Get it here:
http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=109394. Deploy and run.
Need to install the valid DB and the problem arises with any web service call
like for example login into the admin part (user & pass = admin by default).

Let me know if further info is needed.
creator: javier.ortiz.78@gmail.com

text: Thanks for letting us know. Please only create a report about specific issues.
creator: remm@apache.org
bugzilla@schoenhaber.de
text:
(In reply to comment #3)
> The running aplication is an open source program. Get it here:
> http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=109394. Deploy and run.
> Need to install the valid DB and the problem arises with any web service call
> like for example login into the admin part (user & pass = admin by default).
> 
> Let me know if further info is needed.

I downloaded and installed Xinco, started XincoExplorer, logged in, added some
data, viewed the new data in XincoPublisher and I didn't experience any problem
at all.
Therefore i suspect what you're seeing is not a Tomcat bug but a user error. You
might want to ask for help in the Xinco forums or the Tomcat users list.
There, you should provide specific information about what exactly you did, what
exacly happened when you did it etc. Otherwise it will be very hard for others
to help you.

(In reply to comment #5)
All this done in Tomcat 6? I'm actually a Xinco developer so trust me it's not
Xinco. I guess you deployed the war file from tomcat and I'm trying to deploy
from Netbeans and that might be the key there.

Thanks anyways!
creator: javier.ortiz.78@gmail.com

text:
(In reply to comment #6)
> All this done in Tomcat 6?

Yes.

> I'm actually a Xinco developer so trust me

Hm, you provided almost no information I could choose to trust or not.

> it's not Xinco.

Maybe. And I've yet to see the merest hint that it might be Tomcat's fault.

> I guess you deployed the war file from tomcat and I'm trying to deploy from
> Netbeans and that might be the key there.

Might be worth to check...
creator: bugzilla@schoenhaber.de

text:
Personally, I'm almost never going to look into an issue which involves
installing things (this is what paid support does). If it's an important issue,
then it will be reported in a more sensible way (incl traces, test cases,
whatever) very quickly.
creator: remm@apache.org
